awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC Phase I: Broadband Wireless Access and Applications Center at the University of Mississippi
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will help create a new I/UCRC Site at University of Mississippi (UM) to join an existing IUCRC called BWAC (Broadband Wireless access and Applications Center) led by University of Arizona which started in July 2013. The UM site extends the scope of BWAC in the areas of computational electromagnetics (EM), antenna design and testing, and telecommunications. This Site will add two of the largest industries in the wireless space, Qualcomm and Intel, to the BWAC Industrial Advisory Board. The BWAC site will help recruit diverse and promising undergraduate and graduate students into electrical engineering undergraduate and graduate programs at UM. By engaging them directly in research on problems of actual interest to corporate partners, BWAC will help prepare these students to compete and be productive in corporate jobs the day they graduate.

This project will bring to bear UM research capabilities and real-world industry interest in areas that align with the focus of BWAC. The UM faculty have identified potential industry-oriented research in the areas of metamaterials for antenna cloaking, mmWave antennas, wireless signaling from embedded sensors for concussion management in college athletic sports, fountain codes for big data transfers, cognitive radios and radar systems. Other possible applications areas include, wireless connectivity for improved efficiency in factory, new wireless security algorithms, applications of wireless sensor networks, and telemedicine.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project was to conduct company driven research in broadband wireless access and applications and disseminate the findings to the technical community. Pursued focus areas included metamaterials and antenna, additive manufacturing methods for antennas and RF devices, coexistence of cognitive radios and licensed systems, coexistence of WiFi and Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) enabled systems in factory environments, and embedded wireless systems for athletic concussion research.

Intellectual merits of the project span two aspects of antenna design and two environments where interference among competing wireless systems necessitate careful design considerations.

The objective of antenna cloaking project was to explore the operational principles and underlying phenomena behind metasurface cloaks to cloak and decouple closely spaced antennas and overlapping planar phased antenna arrays. Simulation and theoretical results confirm the effectiveness of metasurface cloaks involving both discrete antennas and phased array antennas. Results are expected to be useful for next generation wireless systems for both commercial and military applications. The objective of 3-D printing RF devices and antennas was to investigate the characteristics of printed devices that have been fabricated using 3D printers. A range of printers were used, from filament only to print substrates to filament and conductive ink printers to print entire microstrips.   Insight gained by 3D printing into the role infill rate plays in the variation of permittivity led to development of a volumetric infill-rate simulation model that yields the variation of permittivity, which will be useful in antenna design.

The LAA/WiFi coexistence project investigated access probabilities, air occupancy times, and then throughputs of LAA and WiFi systems in various coexistence scenarios.  By using Markov chain-based modeling, it was determined that contention window sizes in an LAA can be tuned to achieve acceptable fairness in both throughput and airtime. Specific objectives of WiFi/BLE project were to develop analytical and simulation tools to guide parameter selection and performance analysis of BLE-based scanning systems in the presence of WiFi and other industrial RF interference. Students designed experiments and wrote programs to manage real time advertisement and scanning processes and collect and analyze data. Simulation showed that analytical modeling yielded highly accurate average performance estimates but also substantially underestimated the required scanning times due to unexpected correlation in the collision process.

Broader impacts of the project were workforce development and outreach.

Four undergraduate and four MS students gained valuable research expertise through contributing to the projects.  Four students were hired by our member companies upon graduation, and three students continued to work towards Ph.D. degrees. Research findings from the antenna cloaking project and 3-D printing of antenna project were incorporated into senior level undergraduate elective and design courses. Some UG students learned to program USRPs using GNU radio in their UG research experience.   In the athletic concussions project, two STEM summer camps for high school students in and around Mississippi were hosted. Those students learned about nutrition, wireless connectivity, and how to use a smart phone app to monitor the health of athletes on and off the field.
